org.threadly.concurrent.collections
Class DynamicDelayQueue<T extends java.util.concurrent.Delayed>

java.lang.Object
  org.threadly.concurrent.collections.DynamicDelayQueue<T>
Type Parameters:
T - Parameter to indicate what type of item is contained in the queue
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Iterable<T>, java.util.Collection<T>, java.util.concurrent.BlockingQueue<T>, java.util.Queue<T>
public class DynamicDelayQueue<T extends java.util.concurrent.Delayed>
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.util.Queue<T>, java.util.concurrent.BlockingQueue<T>

This queue is very similar to java.util.concurrent.DelayQueue but has one major difference. This queue is designed around the idea that items can change their delay. This is needed in the PriorityScheduledExecutor in order to ensure that task removal requests can always be found in the queue. Items enter the queue with Long.MAX_VALUE delay, and then will just call reposition once they know when their next execution time is.

Constructor Detail

DynamicDelayQueue

public DynamicDelayQueue()
Constructs a new DynamicDelayQueue queue.

DynamicDelayQueue

public DynamicDelayQueue(VirtualLock queueLock)
Constructs a queue, providing the lock that will be called on with .await(). Thus it allows you to synchronize around the .take() and have the lock released while the thread blocks.

Parameters:
queueLock - lock that is used internally
Method Detail

toString

public java.lang.String toString()

getLock

public VirtualLock getLock()
Returns the VirtualLock that will be called with .await during take. And must be synchronized on while using the iterator.

Returns:
lock synchronized on internally

sortQueue

public void sortQueue()
Does a full sort on the queue, this is usually not optimal. It is better to call reposition(T e), but this could be used if many items moved at the same time.

reposition

public void reposition(T e)
Called to reposition an item in the queue which's delay has updated since original insertion (or was originally inserted as addLast().

Parameters:
e - item currently in the queue

addLast

public void addLast(T e)
Adds an item to the end of the queue, used as an optimization from add(T e) when it is known the item will be at the end of the queue.

Parameters:
e - item to add to queue
